153.33.text: we always get asked to play.

154.96.text:
They say, "Will you come and do a talk?".
And I say, "Yes, I'd love to, thanks".

158.77.text:
And they say, "Of course we'll bring
a piano so you can play too."

163.03.text: I often think, well, what if Gordon Ramsay

165.74.text: was coming here to talk about something?

167.67.text:
They wouldn't bring an oven onstage
and say,

169.77.text:
"Cook us a fucking cake or something",
would they?

173.24.text: But that's fine, I love playing.

176.31.text: It's sad, but it's true but this thing...

179.58.text:
is kind of my best friend.
(Laughter)

184.33.text: A lot of you will know that piece,

186.41.text: I imagine, that I just played.

189.47.text:
And some of you might know
that it was written by Bach

193.05.text: and maybe a few of you will know

200.31.text: But I'm going to say something now

202.11.text: that I think most of you won't know.

205.89.text:
And this whole conference
is about trust, isn't it?

211.78.text: I don't trust a fucking thing.

213.27.text:
I don't trust anyone,
I don't trust anything.

217.10.text:
and I want you to trust me
when I tell you this:

221.76.text: There is not a single person

224.53.text: in this room today or watching this online

228.62.text:
who would not be able
to play that piece of music

234.24.text:
Even if you've never touched
a piano before

237.31.text:
so long as you've got
two hands and ten fingers

240.19.text: you would be able to play that piece

245.83.text:
I've just written a book
that explains how to do it.

248.28.text:
It shows you how to read music,
how to practice...

251.03.text: You don't even need a proper piano,

252.82.text:
you can get a cheap electric keyboard
and you can still do it.

256.96.text:
I just realised it's been 3 minutes
into my talk

259.24.text: and I've already plugged the book.

261.04.text:
I'm really sorry.
I'm not going to do that again.

263.34.text: But the point is that music

265.18.text: that piece is, what - 90 seconds long?

281.55.text: I can't think of anything else

284.61.text: in the world in which we live

286.36.text: that it is as universal as music.

294.30.text: Not English football because we're shit.

305.77.text:
"Classical music
is the deepest of the arts

308.49.text: and it goes deep beneath the arts."

311.76.text:
And it's one of those things
that it's like a language

314.93.text:
that we don't know
that we're all fluent in.

318.09.text: It's amazing and so learning an instrument

322.63.text: is something that I think we need more of

325.25.text: in the world in which we live today.

327.34.text: Because that world in which we live today,

335.84.text:
and we see introverts
as kind of freaks, to be honest.

339.99.text:
I think it should be the other
way around.

342.35.text:
Everything we do today
is predicated on the idea

347.53.text:
that looking outside of ourselves
is the right thing to do.

351.80.text: You know we post selfies on Instagram,

356.29.text: we are funny or argumentative on Twitter,

359.41.text:
we poke people on Facebook,
we swipe on Tinder,

361.84.text: we buy shit we don't need from Amazon,

365.37.text: we do so many things looking outside

368.68.text: to try and make what's happening inside

371.28.text: feel just a little bit better.

373.97.text:
And weirdly,
we've got it the wrong way around.

379.50.text: Two weeks ago I was in Madrid

381.04.text: and I was doing a concert here

382.49.text:
and in the concert I was playing
a piece of Beethoven.

386.43.text:
In the morning of the concert
I walk down to the Prado museum.

389.70.text: Oh my God what a place!

391.91.text: And I went to see the Goya paintings.

394.88.text:
He did a series of paintings called
"The black paintings."

400.90.text:
Goya and Beethoven
have a lot of similarities.

405.09.text:
I guess most importantly they went deaf
at the same time, both of them.

413.85.text:
he spent time living under a bridge
not far from here in Madrid.

419.43.text: because the police thought he was a tramp,

424.48.text:
But the real reason
they're so connected is that,

431.53.text:
to express what was going on
in the outside world.

435.79.text:
Goya painted the ugly truth
that people needed to see.

440.67.text:
Beethoven ripped up the rule book
and he composed music

444.37.text:
that really for the first time
in musical history

448.31.text:
was about feelings,
it was about interiority, looking inside.

452.56.text: It wan't about the glory of God,

456.27.text: making the people paying him happy

464.86.text: all of us today, myself included

470.32.text: how to shut the fuck up.

474.47.text: And just sit and be still and just be.

478.95.text:
Things are so fast
we've forgotten how to listen,

481.40.text: how to really listen and hear.

484.94.text: If I say to my girlfriend,

490.36.text: and she looks at me and she says,

495.36.text:
It's not just me, right?
That happens to all.

498.66.text:
I know then, whatever I say,
I'm in trouble.

500.91.text: There's nothing I can say to that.

502.68.text:
If I say to her,
"Baby, what's wrong?"

504.69.text: And she looks at me and she says,

506.36.text:
"You know, this morning when you
said that thing it really upset me."

513.86.text: And we have somewhere to go,

515.25.text:
we have communication,
and dialogue and honesty.

518.11.text:
And I often wonder what would happen
if we were all a bit more honest

521.76.text: about what was going on in the inside.

525.53.text:
It's an extraordinary thing to be able
to do, it's a brave thing to do.

529.22.text: Would the world be a better place?

532.63.text: Would it be a more trustworthy place?

536.61.text: There's no doubt in my mind.

540.34.text:
Like I said,
I find it very difficult to trust.

545.73.text:
I had a quite challenging
childhood and upbringing.

549.00.text: Lots of us have, of course.

550.48.text:
We all go through trauma
in one way or another.

555.23.text: And I actually wrote a book about it,

557.00.text:
that some of you
have been kind enough to buy

559.15.text:
and some of you have even read it
which is very kind of you,

565.67.text:
It's really a love letter to music
but it also talks about -

568.60.text:
it's basically a book about
child rape and classical music.

577.05.text:
"Yes this will be in supermarkets
everywhere,

579.22.text: everyone wants to know about that stuff."

581.97.text:
But the truth is,
the reason I bring it up

584.78.text: it's a love letter to music

586.26.text: because music is the one thing

588.37.text: that when bad things were happening

591.49.text: Even today when shit is going wrong

594.70.text: I listen to music and everything changes.

597.49.text:
You know they say that the soul
resides at that junction point

603.18.text: between our inner and our outer worlds.

606.18.text:
That small space between
dreams and fantasy and reality.

615.60.text: are when I get back to that place

617.93.text: even if it's only for a short time

621.62.text:
that's the space they inhabited
and they created from.

625.31.text:
And I want to mention a word,
I'm really sorry for mentioning it

633.29.text:
I'm sorry, you know,
I often thought mindfulnes meant

635.84.text:
you kind of hire a fleet
of commando monks with shaved heads

639.96.text: and you climb up a mountain

641.66.text:
and you "om" for three weeks,
while fasting.

652.42.text:
Playing the piano, listening to music
listening, really listening...

664.38.text: I'm not a religious man at all.

668.09.text: But I've got a lot of faith

669.39.text: I've got a lot of faith but no religion.

671.31.text: But there is no greater proof

696.50.text:
And that is a much, much,
much stronger list of things

700.06.text:
to help us connect
to that part of ourselves than

708.24.text:
any one of the dozens
of medications and drugs

710.54.text: that I've taken over the years.

713.63.text: And of course medication is important

716.03.text: it kept me alive for a bit.

719.13.text: But music is where the real magic happens.

731.52.text: and the premise behind everyone of them

733.87.text:
is that you have all
completely fucked up your life.

737.47.text: You've done everything wrong for decades,

741.46.text:
you're a complete failure
as a human being.

746.29.text: But if you read this book,

748.39.text:
I'll convince you
to buy the next book I write,

751.14.text: that will say the same thing.

755.08.text: We don't need it because the truth is,

759.21.text: is that every single one of you

762.65.text: You're perfect just the way you are.

765.91.text:
And the way to get in touch
with that part of us

770.62.text:
is to listen and to connect
and to celebrate this idea of interiority.

778.78.text:
And music, the saddest thing
is that we know how powerful it is,

782.44.text: we all know the impact it has.

790.51.text:
It's not just in England,
although England is appalling.

794.04.text:
I was in the House of Lords
three days ago,

797.07.text:
speaking to a big group of people
all about music education.

801.39.text:
non of them have a fucking clue
of what to do.

803.67.text: They just haven't got a clue,

805.29.text:
they don't listen, they can't listen
they don't know how to fix it.

808.75.text:
And the truth is
unless you have money today,

811.72.text: your kids aren't going to learn music.

814.69.text: They aren't going to know who Bach is,

816.74.text: they're not going to know that piece.

818.55.text:
And so it falls on us
as people who are creative

823.24.text:
and who were lucky enough
to be able to listen and explore music,

830.03.text: One of the things I really want to do

831.93.text: is to form, to build, to develope an app -

837.02.text:
there are not enough of them. 
(Laughter)

841.26.text: And this app will celebrate interiority

843.45.text:
and what it will do
is it will provide you everyday

846.83.text: with a piece of classical music.

848.50.text:
I hate the phrase 'classical music',
by the way

850.79.text:
I'm sorry I keep mentioning it
but there is no other phrase, does it?

854.93.text:
classical musicians
and the people in the industry

858.68.text: They keep classical music up here

862.83.text: and just for a certain kind of audience

864.76.text:
who are well-dressed and educated
and wealthy and they can understand it

870.05.text: If anyone can suggest a better phrase

874.64.text:
I did that on Twitter
and people were saying things like

887.39.text: is that you'll will find this app,

889.76.text: it will send you a piece of music,

895.67.text:
and you will send to people you love,
you miss, you're thinking about,

899.94.text: you'll send them a little piece of music,

902.00.text:
and you will listen to it yourself
and just for 5 minutes a day,

906.35.text:
and reconnect
with that interior part of yourself,

909.34.text: and see what the impact is.

913.12.text: So I'd like to do a little experiment now,

916.90.text: I'd like imagine that I've given you all

923.63.text:
I've given you all this app
on your smartphones

925.92.text:
and you pull out your smartphones
and you open up the app

928.60.text: and now I want us to go really quiet.

935.47.text:
It doesn't matter you can't see me now,
this is about listening.

939.65.text:
I want us to learn how to listen again,
to reconnect to that part of ourselves

943.42.text:
I'm going to play you a piece of music
by a composer called Gluck.

948.67.text:
And when I'm playing it
I want you to close your eyes and trust

953.09.text: what's going to happen to you.

955.15.text: Trust, listen to your heart beating

957.62.text: feel what a miracle you are

959.45.text: trust this music will tunnel into you

961.73.text:
and take you to a place that is safe
and extraordinary and powerful.

973.64.text:
just to connect with something,
some kind of inner beauty.

976.93.text:
And if it's not learning an instrument
or listening to music

979.94.text:
it can be painting, or drawing,

984.50.text: or any one of a thousand creative things

989.39.text:
to the the fucked up,
